# Task

Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example



# Special Instructions

None.

Here is the Julia code that solves your problem:

```julia
function wrap_string(s::String, text_width::Int = 10)
    words = split(s, ' ')
    result = ""
    current_line = ""
    for word in words
        if length(current_line * " $word") > text_width
            result *= "$current_line\n"
            current_line = word
        else
            current_line *= " $word"
        end
    end
    return result * current_line
end
```
This function splits the input string into words, and then iterates over each word. If adding a new word to the current line would exceed `text_width`, it starts a new line for that word. It then returns the final string with lines separated by newline characters `\n`. 

For example, if you call `wrap_string("Hello world", 10)`, it will return `"Hello\nworld"`, because "Hello" and "world" fit into one line of width 10 each. But if you call `wrap_string("Hello world this is a test", 10)`, it would return `"Hello\nworld this\nis a test"`.
